title: Making money takes practice like playing the piano takes practice
descr:
From Medium, by Jason Fried

https://medium.com/@jasonfried/making-money-takes-practice-like-playing-the-piano-takes-practice-41a72ab51a68

Most of the people I know who are money-making-machines got started really early. Lemonade stands, car washes, lawn mowing, baseball card trading. I think the reason they are money-making-machines today is because they started early. They learned the skills of negotiation, pricing, selling, and market-reading early. They have more practice selling than most people. That’s one of the reasons they’re better at it than most people.

Making money takes practice, just like playing the piano takes practice. No one expects anyone to be any good at the piano unless they’ve put in lots practice. Same with making money. The better you practice the better you get. Eventually making money is as easy for you as piano is for someone who’s been playing for 10 years.

This is one of the reasons I encourage entrepreneurs to bootstrap instead of taking outside money. On day one, a bootstrapped company sets out to make money. They have no choice, really. On day one a funded company sets out to spend money. They hire, they buy, they invest, they spend. Making money isn’t important yet. They practice spending, not making.

Bootstrapping puts you in the right mindset as an entrepreneur. You think of money more as something you make than something you spend. That’s the right lesson, that’s the right habit, the right imprint on your business brain. You’re better off as an entrepreneur if you have more practice making money than spending money. Bootstrapping gives you a head start.

So if you’re about to start a business, or if you already have a business and you’re thinking about taking funding, or if you’ve already taken funding and are considering going back for more, consider the alternative. Don’t raise money, raise prices. Sell sell sell. Get as much practice as you can. Force yourself to practice. Force yourself to learn how to make money as early as you can. You may hate it in the short-term, but it’ll make you a great businessperson in the long term.

title: NoMethodError undefined method loaded_recipe
subtitle: (system) (rbenv::system line 28) had an error: NoMethodError: undefined method `loaded_recipe?' chef 10.18, chef 11 devops opscode
descr: The problem comes from the matter of chef 11 introducing some breaking changes from chef 10. You are looking to have the chef-rbenv version that is compatible with chef 10 (or chef 10.18). You can find it here: https://github.com/Piousbox-cookbooks/chef-rbenv

title: The proxy server received an invalid response from an upstream server.
descr:
The following error:


Proxy Error

The proxy server received an invalid response from an upstream server.
The proxy server could not handle the request POST /photos.

Reason: Error reading from remote server

Apache/2.2.20 (Ubuntu) Server at organizer.annesque.com Port 80

 

Is solved by the following unicorn.rb config file. Notice the number of workers and timeout  value:


worker_processes 8

working_directory "/home/ubuntu/projects/microsites2/current"

listen "/tmp/microsites2.sock", :backlog => 64
listen 8085, :tcp_nopush => true

timeout 300

pid "/home/ubuntu/projects/microsites2/current/tmp/pids/unicorn.pid"

stderr_path "/home/ubuntu/projects/microsites2/shared/log/microsites2.unicorn.stderr.log"
stdout_path "/home/ubuntu/projects/microsites2/shared/log/microsites2.unicorn.stdout.log"

preload_app true
GC.respond_to?(:copy_on_write_friendly=) and
  GC.copy_on_write_friendly = true

before_fork do |server, worker|
  # defined?(ActiveRecord::Base) and
  #   ActiveRecord::Base.connection.disconnect!

  # old_pid = "#{server.config[:pid]}.oldbin"
  # if old_pid != server.pid
  #   begin
  #     sig = (worker.nr + 1) >= server.worker_processes ? :QUIT : :TTOU
  #     Process.kill(sig, File.read(old_pid).to_i)
  #   rescue Errno::ENOENT, Errno::ESRCH
  #   end
  # end
 
  sleep 1
end

after_fork do |server, worker|
  # defined?(ActiveRecord::Base) and
  #   ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection
 
end

 

Here is my virtual host for good measure:


<VirtualHost *:80>

  ServerAdmin piousbox@gmail.com

  ProxyPreserveHost On
  ProxyVia On
  Keepalive On

  SetEnv force-proxy-request-1.0 1
  SetEnv proxy-nokeepalive 1
  setenv proxy-initial-not-pooled 1

  ServerName organizer.annesque.com

  ServerAlias annesque.com
  ServerAlias piousbox.com
  ServerAlias travel-guide.mobi
 
  <proxy>
    Order deny,allow
    Allow from all
  </proxy>

  ProxyPass / http://x.x.x.x:8080/  connectiontimeout=400 timeout=400 Keepalive=On
  ProxyPassReverse / http://x.x.x.x:8080/
 
</VirtualHost>

I manager my infrastructure with Opscode Chef, over AWS.

title: MogileFS to GridFS migration
descr:
MogileFS is pretty old. There are other alternatives out there, we are considering GridFS.

The migration process would look like the following:

  • Discovery
  • Setup GridSF - dev, staging, production. Requires mongodb. Requires extra Chef scripts.
  • Copy over the data from mogileFS to GridFS - this requires a custom script.
  • Swap mogileFS components for GridFS components in the codebase.
  • Done, profit.


Time estimates:

  • Setup - This is Christine's domain, although I will be happy to help. 1.5 days
  • Copy - 1 day
  • Swap - 1.5 days
  • Done - 0-5 days
